titlestmt.titleproper: Register to The Ernest Trow Carter Papers
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Adrienne Scholtz

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:13

did.unittitle: The Ernest Trow Carter Papers
did.abstract: Music, correspondence, photographs, and additional materials by and about the American composer, conductor, and organist Ernest Trow Carter (1866-1953)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment.
Some of the materials may be stored at the Library's off-campus shelving facility, so researchers should allow at least two business days to have the appropriate boxes paged.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Ernest Trow Carter Papers were established in the Music Library of Yale University in 1983 by Carter's grandchildren, Edward L. Richards, Jr., Ernest C. Richards, and Laura L. Robertson.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Ernest Trow Carter Papers are the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 40 The Ernest Trow Carter Papers in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 11 series as follows: I. Music by Carter. II. Music arranged by Carter. III. Music by others. IV. Production materials. V. Correspondence. VI. Programs. VII. Clippings, press notices, and advertisements. VIII. Photographs. IX. Writings. X. Bills, receipts, contracts, and certificates. XI. Memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ernest Trow Carter Papers contain sketches, manuscript scores, and published editions of Carter's musical compositions, including operas, orchestral works, chamber music, keyboard pieces, choral music, and songs. The Papers also contain music composed by others and arranged by Carter. The correspondence includes letters to and from Carter and performers, composers, publishers, musical organizations, and family members. Carter's life and work are further documented by: production materials; programs; clippings; photographs; writings by and about Carter; and financial records and memorabilia.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ernest Trow Carter was born in Orange, New Jersey, on September 3, 1866. He graduated from Princeton University cum laude in 1888. Carter earned an M.A. in law from Columbia University in 1899, and would later receive an honorary Doctor of Music degree from Princeton in 1932.

While at Princeton, Carter led the Glee Club and Chapel Choir, and composed and arranged music for these groups. In 1892 he became musical director of the Thacher School in Ojai, California. Two years later he moved to Berlin to study composition and organ. Upon returning to the United States, Carter resumed his organ studies. He also served as lecturer in music, organist, and choirmaster at Princeton from 1899 to 1901. His interest in composition led him to resign from this position, and during the next year he sang in the Metropolitan Opera Chorus in order to study opera technique.

Carter composed works for orchestra, band, chorus, and keyboard, as well as songs, chamber and instrumental music, and stage works. The three major stage works include two operas, The Blonde Donna and The White Bird, and a ballet-pantomime, Namba. Carter himself wrote the libretto for The Blonde Donna. It premiered in concert form in New York in February 1912. The first full performance was by the New York Opera Comique at the Brooklyn Little Theater on December 8, 1931. The White Bird, composed to a libretto by Brian Hooker, placed second among eighteen entries in the Hinshaw Contest of 1916-1917. Its first performance, also in concert form, was at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall on May 23, 1922, with Carter conducting. The first full performance of The White Bird was at the Studebaker Theater, in Chicago, on March 6, 1924. The Opera in Our Language Foundation sponsored the performance, and awarded Carter the first David Bispham Memorial Medal. On November 15, 1927, The White Bird became the first American opera to be performed at the Municipal Theater of Osnabrück, Germany. Namba was first presented at the Columbus School for Girls in May, 1924, and later performed by the Charlotte Lund Opera Company and the Aleta Doré Ballet at the Shakespeare Theater of New York, on April 22, 1933.
Ernest Trow Carter died in Stamford, Connecticut, on June 21, 1953.

did.unittitle: Music by Carter

odd.head: General
odd.p: This series includes holograph, manuscript, printed, and published music by Carter. The music is divided into nine subseries by genre (A-I). Within each subseries, the works are arranged alphabetically by title. Uniform titles are used to bring together all of the manifestations of a work with various titles. Cross references appear in the index from other forms of a title to the uniform title, between an original work and its arrangements, and for those pieces which are included with another work.
Boxes and folders are numbered consecutively throughout the entire series, with the exception of one oversized box housed at the end of the collection (Box 44).
Subseries I, Carmina Princetonia, includes Princeton songbooks containing music by or arranged by Carter.

did.unittitle: Music Arranged by Carter

odd.head: General
odd.p: This series includes manuscript and published music by others arranged by Carter. The music is arranged alphabetically by composer or title. Uniform titles are used to bring together all of the manifestations of a work with various titles. Cross references appear in the index for those pieces which are included with another work. Folders are numbered consecutively throughout the series.

did.unittitle: Music by Others

odd.head: General
odd.p: This series includes manuscript and published music by others. It is arranged alphabetically by composer or title. Uniform titles are used to bring together all the manifestations of a work within various titles. Cross references appear in the index between music by others in this series and the corresponding arrangements by Carter in Series II. Folders are numbered consecutively throughout the series.

did.unittitle: Production Materials

odd.head: General
odd.p: Production materials include holograph, manuscript, and typescript scenarios, stage directions, sketches for stage plans, timetables of musical numbers, notes, and records of materials and costs. Also included are lists of costumes, musical numbers, characters, properties, tempi, musical themes, rehearsal numbers, lighting, cast, and rehearsal numbers. There are three subseries (A-C) for Carter's stage works: The Blonde Donna; Namba; and The White Bird. Boxes and folders are numbered consecutively throughout the series, with the exception of oversized material, which is housed at the end (Box 44).

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence is divided into three subseries: A. From Carter; B. To Carter; and C. Between Others. The majority of the letters from Carter are typescript copies. These have been copied onto acid-free paper, and only those original letters which are either signed by Carter or contain his notes remain in the collection. The correspondence is arranged alphabetically by recipient or sender, except for the last subseries, which is arranged chronologically. Boxes and folders are numbered consecutively throughout the series. Cross-references appear among the entries. Many letters to Carter contain enclosures or Carter's sketches for his replies on the backs, and notes appear when this occurs.
